question: You can't imagine what just happened. I was coming back on the Lublin road when the wheel came off the cart thank heavens it was the way back and I'd already sold the geese!
answer: How much?

question: Fifteen groshen, but that's not the story. I was struggling to set the cart upright when a droshky approaches from the direction of Lvov. How lucky, you think, that someone is out this late.

question: But that's the least of it! He stops to help me; we talk of this, we talk of that-it turns out this is someone you know! Traitle Groshkover!

question: What?

answer: You talked to a dybbuk. Traitle Groshkover died of typhus in Pesel Bunim's house. Pesel told me-she sat shiva for him.

question: My husband said he offered you soup.
answer: Yes, but I couldn't possibly eat this late, or I'd have nightmares. No, no

question: I knew it.
answer: I see! You think I'm fat enough already!

question: No. A dybbuk doesn't eat.
answer: What a wife you have!

question: Oh my. Oh my yes. What nonsense. And even if there were spirits, certainly... He thumps his chest. I am not one of them!
answer: Pesel always worried. Your corpse was left unattended for many minutes when Pesel's father broke shiva and left the room-it must have been then that the Evil One- She breaks off to spit at the mention of the Evil One. -took you!

question: "My corpse!" Honestly! What a wife you have!
answer: Oh yes? Look, husband...

question: Well, I-sorry. He holds the pack toward LARRY.
answer: No thanks.

question: Well, you're in good health. How're Judith and the kids?
answer: Good. Everyone's good. You know. The DOCTOR takes a long suck.

question: So, uh, what can I do for you? The messages
answer: Uh, Dr. Gopnik, I believe the results of Physics Mid-Term were unjust.

question: Uh-huh, how so?
answer: I received an unsatisfactory grade. In fact

answer: Yes, but this is not just. I was unaware to be examined on the mathematics.

answer: If I receive failing grade I lose my scholarship, and feel shame. I understand the physics. I understand the dead cat. Very difficult... very difficult...

question: Well, I... I'm sorry, but I... what do you propose?
answer: Passing grade.

question: No no, I-
answer: Or perhaps I can take the mid-term again. Now I know it covers mathematics.

question: Well, the other students wouldn't like that, would they. If one student gets to retake the test til he gets a grade he likes. CLIVE impassively considers this.

question: . No, I'm afraid-
answer: Hush-hush.

question: No, that's just not workable. I'm afraid we'll just have to bite the bullet on this thing, CLIVE, and-

question: You know what it is! You know what it is! I believe. And
answer: Of course, sir.

question: I'll have to pass it on to Professor Finkle, along with my suspicions about where it came from. Actions have consequences.

question: Always! Actions always have consequences! He pounds the desk for emphasis. In this office, actions have consequences!

question: . Meer sir my sir?

question: Arthur? Uncle Arthur does not look up from his scribbling. Uncle Arthur Yes. LARRY continues to stare at the ceiling. What're you doing? question: Uh-huh.

question: Well, I guess...

question: You know, Sy-
answer: Open it-let it breathe. Ten minutes. Letting it breathe, so impawtant.

question: Thanks, Sy, but I'm not-
answer: I insist! No reason for discumfit. I'll be uncumftable if you don't take it. These are signs and tokens, LARRY.

question: Go scrub up, Mitch.
answer: Uh, good afternoon. This brings Gar's look around. Apparently he is unused to talking with his neighbor. There is a short beat before his response.

question: Afternoon. In the background of his angle is the dead buck, staring off through sightless eyes. Yep.
answer: Is that a, uh... He is indicating the staked area. Gar looks around at it, looks back at LARRY.

question: Gonna be a den.
answer: Uh-huh, that's great. Uh, Mr. Brandt- Gar barks at Mitch, who has lingered to listen to the grown-ups:

question: I said scrub up, Mitch! The child quickly goes. LARRY frowns.
answer: Isn't this a school day?

question: Took him out of school today. So he could hunt with his dad.
answer: Oh! He nods. . That's.. . nice. Gar stares at him with button eyes. Small talk is not his thing. LARRY clears his throat.

question: Property line's the poplar.
answer: . the. ?

question: Poplar!
answer: . Well.. . even if it is, you're just about over it

question: Measure. We hear two pairs of pounding footsteps coming up the street.

question: Line's the poplar. He indicates. . It's all angles. Gar Brandt turns and goes. LARRY turns, reacting to the pounding footsteps. Husky, shaggy-haired, he watches, scowling, as DANNY goes up the walk to his house. LARRY addresses DANNY's retreating back:
answer: What's going on?

question: I'm going to the hole.
answer: At five o'clock? He looks out the front-door window. Four girls of SARAH's age are coming up the walk

question: We're stopping at Laurie Kipperstein's house so I can wash my hair. LARRY pulls open the door just as the doorbell rings. From the four dark girls:

question: We're meeting Sy at Embers.

question: Well, for instance, the Jolly Roger is quite livable. Not expensive, and the rooms are eminently livable.

question: There's convenience in its fava. There's a pool-

question: LARRY, you're jesting!

question: No. Almost a year and a half since Touche Ross let him go. He's very good with numbers. I think his, his social skills have held him back.
answer: Such a sweet man though.

question: Arthur has a good heart. And he never complains, unlike me. Sometimes I don't give him enough credit.
answer: He tried to tell me about this thing he's working on, this, um...

question: The Mentaculus? He says it's a, uh. a probability map. Of the universe. He asked if I could help him publish it. Um, it was a little hard for me to evaluate.
answer: Does he go out socially at all?

question: He tries. He's been going to the singles mixers at Hillel House.-Well, I should talk, I'm not doing any better.

question: Fine. She's fine. I'm the odd man out. Mimi smiles.
answer: Sometimes these things just aren't meant to be. And it can take a while before you feel what was always there, for better or worse.

question: I never felt it! It was a bolt from the blue! What does that mean! Everything that I thought was one way turns out to be another!
answer: Then-it's an opportunity to learn how things really are. LARRY broods. Mimi softens. . I'm sorry-I don't mean to sound glib. It's not always easy, deciphering what God is trying to tell you.

question: I'll say.
answer: But it's not something you have to figure out all by your- self. We're Jews, we have that well of tradition to draw on, to help us understand. When we're puzzled we have all the

answer: Have you talked to Rabbi Nachtner? Silence. Arthur is climbing the hill from the lake, dripping wet. He projects:

question: Don.
answer: How are you, LARRY, Jesus, I am so sorry to be seeing you under these circumstances.

question: Oh, well...
answer: I always thought you and JUDY were rock solid. This is so terrible, LARRY. This is devastating.

question: Well, the way I look at it, it's an opportunity for me to really sit down and figure things out, and, and, look at the world afresh instead of just, you know, settling for the routine, tired old way of looking at things. Don Milgram stares at him.
answer: . Really? Well, legally, I have to warn you, it's never easy for the husband. Unless, of course, there's some question of the wife having violated the marriage contract.

question: Oh no, nothing like that. She's planning to marry Sy Ableman, but they-
answer: Sy Ableman!

question: Yes, but they-
answer: Esther is barely cold!

question: No. I'm fairly certain this is not an issue. And in fact they, uh, Judith wants a Gett. Beat. Don stares blankly at LARRY. LARRY clears his throat. A ritual divorce.

question: Oh, they're very... He gropes. . resilient.
answer: Good. Well. On the other thing, the neighbor's property line, I've asked Solomon Schlutz to take a look. There's very little having to do with real estate that'll get by Sol.

question: DANNY? !

question: . What?

answer: Sir, you are Lawrence Gopnik of 1425 Flag Avenue South?

question: Okay.

question: Okay, yes, Lawrence Gopnik, yes.

answer: To receive the monthly main selection you do nothing.

answer: You're about to get Cosmo's Factory, sir. The June main selection. And you haven't-

answer: Are you okay?

answer: Okay. Good. Well, you had fourteen days to listen to Santana Abraxis and return it if you weren't completely satisfied. You did nothing. And now you-

Don projects .Sol? Solomon Schlutz's face now passes from the red end of the spectrum to the purple. Solomon Schlutz Nnnnff! The pipe clatters out of his hand. The hand grabs at his own shirt front. . Glufffl... Now his head pitches back. His backflung weight and twisting body send his chair tipping over, one hand still clutching at his chest while the other frantically waves. He disappears behind the conference table and lands with a floor-shaking thump. His writhing and gurgling remain audible. Sol! Sol! Don Milgram has risen to look down at his fallen colleague; now he flings open the conference room door and bellows into the office

question: Arthur... ? Arthur? Arthur is a dim mound on the next bed. His weeping continues. For no reason LARRY continues to keep his voice to a whisper
answer: AAAHHHH! Shockingy loud, the scream is hard to interpret. Arthur flings off his bedclothes. He leaps from the bed and runs to the door. In boxer shorts and undershirt he flings the door open and runs out of the room.

question: Arthur! LARRY leaps from his bed, also in his underwear. He goes to the door but pauses, peering cautiously outside. Satisfied that the courtyard is deserted, he plunges into it.

answer: I think so... yeah... there... He indicates the road ahead.

question: Okay.. . He straightens. Arthur straightens. LARRY hugs him. .Look... They separate and LARRY pulls a white envelope from his pocket and gives it to Arthur. . This'll help you get back on your feet. Arthur looks into the envelope.
